column7: *TRAVELING* Rembrandt to Monet: 500 Years of European Painting from the Clowes Collection and the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields
column8:
For the first time in its history, the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields will loan the very best of its European paintings as a traveling exhibition, while the Museum undergoes renovations to several of its European galleries.

The works selected for loan have been chosen for their exceptional quality, and for their ability to clearly convey the broader narrative of European art history, from the early Italian Renaissance to nineteenth-century French Impressionism.  This expansive chronological and geographic range includes the most influential periods and schools of European art history, which are represented by masterpieces of Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, Goya, Gauguin, and Monet, among others.

column7: *TRAVELING* Rembrandt to Monet: 500 Years of European Painting from the Clowes Collection and the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields
column8:

The works selected for loan have been chosen for their exceptional quality, and for their ability to clearly convey the broader narrative of European art history, from the early Italian Renaissance to nineteenth-century French Impressionism.  This expansive chronological and geographic range includes the most influential periods and schools of European art history, which are represented by masterpieces of Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, Goya, Gauguin, and Monet, among others.

column8:
For the first time in its history, the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields will loan the very best of its European paintings as a traveling exhibition, while the Museum undergoes renovations to several of its European galleries.

The works selected for loan have been chosen for their exceptional quality, and for their ability to clearly convey the broader narrative of European art history, from the early Italian Renaissance to nineteenth-century French Impressionism. Contemporary works on paper play with language, legibility, and meaning with images that include writing, or forms that resembles writing, but which cannot be  read  conventionally. It includes works by artists who 1) created alphabets of symbols with secret meanings and explored markmaking inspired by scripts from other cultures, and 2) works by artists who used the formal qualities of familiar letters and words to create abstract works of art.  Visitors will be encouraged to think about how we  read  images and create meaning.

column7: Private Eye: The Imagist Impulse in Chicago Art
column8:
In the late 1960s, a group of young artists in Chicago began exhibiting together at the Hyde Park Art Center under exhibition titles that included   The Hairy Who ,  Nonplussed Some  and  The False Image .  By the mid 1970s, this group became collectively known as  The Chicago Imagists .  Their instantly recognizable, highly expressive style is unique and sets their work apart from contemporary art that was produced on the East or West Coasts.  Now, more than 50 years after their first shows, the Chicago Imagists are regarded as among the most important post-war American artists.

The Robertson-Slapak collection is one of the most comprehensive private collections of Chicago Imagist art, possessing key pieces from each of the Imagist artists.  It has been promised to the IMA with two pieces already donated.  It also has holds works of Chicago-based artists from the preceding generation (known as  Monster Roster) as well as those who were the contemporaries and closely related colleagues of the Imagists.

THE LUME Indianapolis will feature nearly 150 state-of-the-art digital projectors that can transform two-dimensional paintings into a three-dimensional world that guests can explore through all their senses. The exhibition featured in THE LUME will move far beyond the static nature of traditional art exhibitions. The LUME Indianapolis will be a new permanent attraction at Newfields, with the first year s show featuring the breathtaking paintings of Vincent van Gogh. Friends and families of all ages are sure to enjoy the fascinating world of Van Gogh and his captivating art in a brand-new light.

FriendsWithYou is the fine art collaborative of Samuel Borkson and Arturo Sandoval III, working collectively since 2002 with the sole purpose of spreading the positive message of Magic, Luck, and Friendship!. Known for immersive installations and interactive artworks
column9: FriendsWithYou invites viewers of their work to reconnect with and reinterpret their lives through communal experiences. The artists  work in a variety of mediums including painting
column14: virtual reality and animation. Incorporating the healing arts

column20: enabling both personal and shared experiences. FriendsWithYou s mission is to cultivate moments of spiritual awareness and powerful

Director s Choice rotation for 2021. This is a selection of recent acquisitions across collections at the IMA.

Indy s Black Lives Matter street mural on Indiana Avenue is an artistic expression of the Black Lives Matter movement created by eighteen Indy-based Black artists. Using art, it provided a place to amplify the messages of the BLM movement, combat racial inequality, and celebrate Black art, space, and togetherness. This exhibition will feature a recreation of the street mural printed on vinyl and likely wrapping around the 3 walls of the gallery. It will also focus on each of the 18 individual artists in the exhibition, recognizing them as individual creatives with diverse and multivalent artistic practices. Music and/or sound will be used to evoke an immersive understanding of the mural and the day it was painted. Video interviews with artists will most likely be conducted by our media team. There is no checklist as no loaned artworks will be used in the space everything will be reproductions.

column7: Indiana Black Expo: IBE 50th Anniversary Gala, Photography Display
column8: Newfields will provide in-kind service to frame and deliver 86 historical, black & white and color photos.  None of the photographs were taken by Newfields Staff.  The photos were gathered by Indiana Black Expo (IBE) from a variety of sources. The event is hosted by Indiana Black Expo.

column7: Juan de Pareja: A Painter's Story
column8: Take a deep dive into the Indianapolis Museum of Art s recently acquired painting, Dog with candle and lilies (early 1660s), by Spanish painter Juan de Pareja. Discover the complicated history of Pareja s journey from enslaved painting assistant to Diego Velzquez, for whom he stretched canvases and ground paint, to a respected independent portrait painter in his own right. Thought to be a fragment of a larger portrait of Saint Dominic, the oil painting of a small dog with a lit candle in its mouth will be exhibited alone in the Davis Lab. Guests are invited to contemplate the artist s remarkable story and share their thoughts in a written response station.

Audience Engagenment Exhibition 
In conjuction with the exhibition Happy World: On a Cloud (EX2021.6), Audience Engagement has mounted a student exhibition.

The exhibition consists entirely of artworks from the museum s permanent collection and will be displayed in a newly renovated corridor of galleries that provides a pathway leading directly to the Clowes Pavilion, which is set to open in early 2022. All of the featured artworks depict the human body and are organized in a global thematic display. 

Embodied explores the motivations behind artworks that depict human figures and the garments that augment them. The installation asks guests to contemplate the question, How do representations of people in art help us explore what it means to be human?  The artwork is arranged into six themes, including power, beauty standards, identity, gender, intimacy and remembrance. As guests make their way through each gallery, they will be encouraged to participate in guided visual literacy exercises. 

The exhibition will feature works spanning 4,000 years and multiple continents and mediums, from painting and sculpture to textiles and ceramics. Guests will recognize artworks from throughout the museum. Notable pieces including The Expulsion of Colin Kaepernick and John Brown vase by Robert Lugo, Barbara Hepworth s Two Figures, Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper, and comingle with dozens of other artworks from the museum s African, American, Asian, Contemporary, Design, Textiles, and Works on Paper collections. 

This reinstallation is led by an interdepartmental team of staff as part of the Gallery Revisioning Project at Newfields. This three-year research and strategic planning endeavor funded by longtime Newfields supporter Kay F. Koch allows the museum to rethink its permanent collection spaces. The group examines ways to engage audiences by displaying the collection in more relevant, inclusive, diverse, interconnected, and experimental ways.

As winter gives way to spring, more than 100,000 new blooms will welcome winter-weary guests to Newfields with flowers around every corner, inside and out. Orchid displays from Newfields  award-winning living collection will captivate audiences in the IMA Galleries, the Madeline F. Elder Greenhouse and Lilly House, and are sure to offer endless inspiration for guests. Spring into the season with the return of Art in Bloom presented by Fifth Third Private Bank, March 31 through April 3. Regional floral artists  arrangements will be exhibited in the IMA Galleries alongside art in the collection. Outside, early signs of spring will emerge with hyacinths and crocus coming to life in The Garden. As the weather warms, hundreds of thousands of colorful blooms will burst to life, culminating with a magnificent crescendo in mid-April. No matter the weather, Spring Blooms presented by Wild Birds Unlimited offers spectacular floral exhibitions around every turn, so come early and often for a breath of fresh air and to see the Newfields  campus evolve.

column7: 90th Annual Juried Exhibition of Indiana Artists, Inc.
column8: The purpose of the Indiana Artists is to hold statewide exhibitions and demonstrations as well as provide social interaction among its members. A board of directors, elected yearly, leads the organization. The Indiana Artists has shown annual exhibits since its

The genius of Hiroshige lay in his ability to depict aspects of Nature in a manner that allowed the viewer to empathize more than simply identify oneself with the figures within his scenes. The images of rain, snow, wind, or even fine weather are evocative to the extent that the viewer feels the need to rush for shelter in the pouring downpour, or to hunch one s shoulders and cover up as much as possible when shelter is unavailable. Or, as in the image of the great pine tree on a rainy night, one can visually  hear  the sound of a steady summer downpour while enjoying the added lyrical sentiments of the accompanying poem emotionally and psychologically placing oneself deeper into the scene. 

This exhibition features four masterworks by Hiroshige featuring rain: 
1)	Shono, Sudden Downpour, from the 53 Stations of the TMkaidM series, is considered one of Hiroshige s greatest masterpieces. 
2)	Evening Shower on the Great Bridge and Atake, as is well known, inspired Vincent Van Gogh to make a copy. 
3)	The Night Rain at Karasaki, part of the hugely popular series, The Eight Views of Lmi, is an iconic print that inspired successive generations of Japanese artists.
4)	The Tsuchiyama is presented in two impressions that allow for comparison and discussion of connoisseurship issues especially in the printing of the rain.

Also for comparison purposes, a work by Tsukioka Yoshitoshi, the great late Edo-Meiji period master,  is included in the exhibition.

Moreover, three 20c works demonstrate Hiroshige s lasting influence into modern times.

column7: Sugar: Commodity and Confection in Art
column8: The history of sugar production has actively shaped Western visual culture in the past half-millennium. This exhibition investigates that relationship using our permanent collection. Starting with the colonial establishment of sugar plantations and the trans-Atlantic slave trade (J.M.W. Turner was a sugar plantation investor and major patrons owned tens of thousands of acres of sugar cane and thousands of slaves in Jamaica), the show will move into sugar as a luxury commodity (using silver and other luxury dessert tools from our decorative  arts collection). It will also include the twentieth century with the transition of sugar to an extremely cheap product and staple of popular culture, with its subsequent high profile in street photography and pop art.

**Dates Tentative**
The Thoma Collection of digital art spans almost the entire history of new media, from 1960s film works by John Cage and Stan VanDerBeek to more contemporary pieces by artists such as Jenny Holzer and Peter Sarkisian. The exhibition hits on many of the key trends and ideas in digital art, including avatars and virtual reality environments, imagery generated spontaneously using randomizing algorithms, imagery and information aggregated from the internet, and the digital manipulation of photography

Stephen Sprouse: Rock | Art | Fashion features more than 60 ensembles and shoes designed by Indiana native Stephen Sprouse (1953 2004) whose transformative styles rocked the fashion world. One of the most innovative and influential American designers, Sprouse is best known for his Day-Glo, graffiti-covered apparel and edgy rock music-inspired collections that combined street style and high fashion. In the late 1970s, he styled the iconic New Wave rock star Debbie Harry for her performances with the band Blondie. His later collections were inspired by the music and counterculture of the 1980s and the innovative energy of circle of his friends such as Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, and Jean-Michel Basquiat. In the 1990s, Sprouse designed exclusive lines for Barney s New York and Bergdorf Goodman. In 2000s, he was hired by Louis Vuitton to graffiti a line of handbags and luggage a collection that sold out immediately, and later designed a collection of clothing and accessories for Target, dubbed as  Americaland,  which became a huge success. Andy Warhol s 1984 double portrait of his close friend Stephen Sprouse will have its Indianapolis debut in the exhibition. This painting, along with another portrait by Warhol, are among the more than 10,000 pieces in the Stephen Sprouse collection that were generously donated to the IMA at Newfields by Joanne Sprouse and Bradford Sprouse, Stephen s mother, and brother.
The goal of this reinterpretation plan is to make Lilly House more accessible to guests as well as create an engaging venue for sharing the history of the Oldfields Estate.

column7: Watercolor Society of Indiana 40th Annual Juried Exhibition
column8: The Watercolor Society of Indiana (WSI) presents the 40th annual juried exhibit of paintings featuring works in a variety of styles. The Society is made up of artists, students, and patron members statewide. WSI artists produce high-quality watercolor paintings and seek to educate the public about the beautiful transparent medium.

A multimedia immersive exhibition produced by Grande Exhibitions. Set to a musical score, a thrilling display of over 3,000 inspirational images transforms every surface   walls, columns, and floors. Traditions of tiptoeing through unnervingly silent galleries and viewing paintings from afar are forgotten as visitors find themselves interacting with art.

column7: Guerrilla Girls: The Art of Behaving Badly
We. The Culture: Works by the Eighteen Art Collective
column8: We. The Culture. is about identity. It s about giving space to the individuality within the 18 Art Collective and lifting up the  who  of 18 Black visual artists based in Indianapolis who have until now, been characterized by their  what.   We. The Culture. is a bright, colorful look into the works of 18 artists shifting the momentum and narrative of American culture, broadly. Confidently identifying themselves as  the Culture,  encourages viewers to know more of who they are as individuals within a collective by way of artwork and to prompt thinking about the influence of Black creativity within American culture.

El Tendedero/The Clothesline Indiana is a participatory artwork by artist and activist Mnica Mayer that/ transforms the clothesline, a symbol of traditional feminine roles, into a forum for conversation on violence against women. The work was previously exhibited at the Indiana Statehouse in support of Women4Change s 2019-2020 efforts to define legal consent in Indiana. At the Statehouse, the participatory artwork garnered over 1,500 responses written on pink postcards from all 92 Indiana counties. As part of this reinstallation, guests will be invited to share their experiences with sexual assault and violence. Guests will leave with a better understanding of this pervasive issue as well as an understanding of how personal stories promoted legislative change in Indiana.

Ujamaa Community Bookstore opened on Juneteenth 2021, bringing together more than 150 local Black artists and entrepreneurs, embodying the spirit of cooperative economics, which is the translation for the Swahili word, Ujamaa. Ujamaa Bookstore welcomes all as a place to celebrate BIPOC creativity and to honor the history of the Black diaspora, and to continue community efforts toward freedom and justice.

The works in this show use, as a point of departure, the landmark event of the Proclamation to end slavery, commemorated by a celebration known as Juneteenth. Art is one of the many tools of survival and liberation which Black people have utilized throughout history. The power of art as an act of liberation and self determination makes it the perfect vehicle to illustrate the many facets of freedom. Within the theme of The Truth of Freedom, we are looking for works that embody the following sub themes: Facing the Past; Celebrating Freedom; and Imagining the Future.

column7: Indiana Black Expo: The 51st Summer Celebration History Exhibit
column8: Newfields will provide in-kind service for exhibition design, installation, and didactics. None of the photographs were taken by Newfields Staff. The photographs were gathered by Indiana Black Expo (IBE) from a variety of sources, documenting Summer Celebration's rich, five-decade history. The event is hosted by Indiana Black Expo.

The Clowes Pavilion was closed in July 2018 for renovation and will reopen in March 2022 (formerly Fall/Winter 2021.) The Clowes Reinstallation will re contextualize objects from The Clowes Collection by presenting them in compelling ways with each other and with objects from other parts of the IMA s permanent collection.

Newfields is proud to present its first-ever all-staff exhibition of artwork by our incredibly talented team members. Artists among Us features 72 original works across 21 departments. For the inaugural show, this promenade has been transformed to feature a rotation of beauty, creativity, and brilliance at Newfields. 
A wide range of media and styles are present in Artists among Us, including paintings, drawings, and sculptures, as well as textile arts, found objects, and the written word. The diverse materials and approaches reflect the breadth and depth of the exceptional minds at Newfields.
Artists among Us is an opportunity for you to get to know us, who we are and what makes us tick, beyond our work bringing life to exhibitions, programs, and festivals at Newfields.

column7: International Violin Competition - Juried Exhibition of Student Art
column8: The Juried Exhibition of Student Art (JESA) one of the most far-reaching multi-disciplinary art projects for grades one through twelve in the state of Indiana. Held in conjunction with the Quadrennial International Violin Competition of Indianapolis, this educational program integrates the performing, literary and visual arts. The 2022 JESA involved over 21,000 school children and 151 art teachers from 57 counties across the state.

column7: Watercolor Society of Indiana 41st Annual Juried Exhibition
91st Annual Juried Exhibition of the Indiana Artists Club, Inc.
column8:
The Indiana Artists Club, Inc. is pleased to present the 91st Annual Juried Exhibition at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields.
	
The Indiana Artists Club, Inc., an Indiana legacy, was founded in 1917 by a group of artists in Brown County, Indiana, and included several members of the original Hoosier Group. The organization connects and empowers diverse artist members through statewide exhibitions, community workshops and social interactions. The Indiana Artist Club promotes its members through its exhibitions, online presence and social media while maintaining connections with statewide business, educational and patron communities.

The 2023 Annual Juried Exhibition was juried by award-winning artist Doreen St. John of Ohio and features 45 pieces created by professional artists currently living and working in Indiana.

Visit the website at www.indianaartists.org.

THE LUME Indianapolis will feature nearly 150 state-of-the-art digital projectors that can transform two-dimensional paintings into a three-dimensional world that guests can explore through all their senses. The exhibition featured in THE LUME will move far beyond the static nature of traditional art exhibitions. The LUME Indianapolis will be a new permanent attraction at Newfields, with the first year s show featuring the breathtaking paintings of Vincent van Gogh. Friends and families of all ages are sure to enjoy the fascinating world of Van Gogh and his captivating art in a brand-new light.

This exhibition features mid-twentieth-century prints from the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields  permanent collection by leading female artists of Atelier 17, a New York printmaking studio, who advanced modernism in print and other media, as well as feminism more broadly, during a time of great change for both in America.
***dates tentative***

column7: The Message is the Medium: Contemporary Art
column8: This exhibition will feature works from Newfields' permanent contemporary collection that have not been on view since the 4th floor was dedicated to LUME.
***dates tentative***
***Title and dates tentative***
Postponed until Spring 2024. See EX2024.11 record.

column7: Work in Progress: Conversations about American Art
column8:
Throughout the history of the United States, its people have debated over who and what places are distinctly American and what qualities represent the nation s essential character. The purpose of this
reinstallation is not to settle these arguments or arrive at a definitive
answer about what, exactly, is  American  instead, these galleries
are an invitation to explore the tensions and disagreements between
different visions of this country, and how those conversations
manifested in the realm of the visual arts

This exhibition features a work by Anicka Yi, an artist who embodies the museum's mission of connecting art and nature. For the installation in EFEP, Yi will create 7 new works from her ongoing series of kelp lamps. These lamps, which are constructed from highly lacquered kelp and contain a small animatronic insect, were previously exhibited at the 2019 Venice Biennale with the title May You Live in Interesting Times. The lamps will hang from the pavilion s center ring and will be illuminated at night. 

Visitors to Newfields will be greeted by a work of contemporary art that underscores the material and conceptual innovations of living artists. Guests will learn that contemporary art can be made from an incredibly wide variety of materials and take inspiration from the natural world in ways that are unique to the present moment.

A survey of Japanese and selections of Korean art from the IMA s permanent collection with a focus on ceramic, metal, and other non-light-sensitive objects that demonstrate both continuity of tradition and innovation within their respective domains.

column7: Walter Lobyn Hamilton What I Have You Have
column8:
What I Have You Have is a visual memoir of interconnectivity through time, experience, genre, family, locality, and memory by Indianapolis-based artist Walter Lobyn Hamilton. The exhibition will feature/ large-scale collages made from vinyl records and album covers.  

Guests are encouraged to disconnect from distractions and immerse themselves in their own personal considerations while they take in the exhibition at the Indianapolis Museum of Art. /  

Uniquely, this exhibition extends beyond the walls of the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Guests are encouraged to explore the exhibition s community partner sites including The Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, University of Indianapolis, and Indianapolis Central Library./

column7: James H. Karales: Selma to Montgomery March
column8: This exhibition features one photograph from the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields' Permanent Collection: Selma to Montgomery March [2008.6] by James H. Karales. The artwork will be on view during the museum's Martin Luther King, Jr. Day programming.

column7: The Truth of Freedom & The Language of Race
column8:
There are many hidden truths to freedom. Taking Juneteenth as a point of departure, The Truth of Freedom & The Language of Race Exhibit explores the words that give shape and sound to our lives- how race is talked about, how it is taught, how it is constructed, misconstrued, and reclaimed.

A visual display of the call and response tradition in Black communities, The Language of Race opens with a call to action. The exhibit moves viewers on journey that begins with an examination of language and imagery used to disparage and disenfranchise Black people. It then moves through explorations of the experiences and realities of these oppressions, and finally, concludes with the loud, outspoken responses of defiant Black voices.
***title and dates tentative***

column7: Newfields at 140: What's Past is Prologue
column8: Newfields has a long history of forward thinking--grounded in the values of our founder--that shapes what we do today and in the future. This exhibition will focus on Newfields throughout its history in Indianapolis and will feature people, especially women, who left their mark on Newfields throughout the years.

The Philadelphia Horticultural Society (PHS) Philadelphia Flower Show is both the nation's largest and the world s longest-running horticultural event, featuring stunning displays by premier floral and landscape designers from around the globe. Started in 1829 by the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, the Show introduces diverse and sustainable plant varieties and garden and design concepts. In addition to acres of garden displays, the Flower Show hosts esteemed competitions in horticulture and artistic floral arranging, gardening presentations and demonstrations, and special events.

2023 PHS Philadelphia Flower Show -  The Garden Electric  
That spark of joy that comes while giving or receiving flowers   this is the moment captured by The Garden Electric. From the dazzling array of colors, unique shapes and textures, and rich fragrances of gorgeous floral displays and gardens come feelings of excitement and celebration. This year s theme brings the electrifying presence of today s most dynamic designers of floral arrangements, lush gardens, and landscapes to visitors from around the world.

column7: Chicago Imagist Art: The Robertson-Slapak Collection
column8: Movement of Chicago Imagist works to dedicated gallery space, K312.

column7: Jeffrey Henson Scales: In A Time of Panthers
column8: Exhibition of five Jeffrey Henson Scales photographs from the IMA Permanent Collection in Waller Gallery for Black History Month. The exhibition includes a guestbook response station, catalogue, and Spotify playlist playing via speakers installed in the gallery.

column7: Mother / Daughter / Ancestor: Threads of Connection
column8: This exhibition explores how women artists employ textiles to honor their matrilineal ancestors. Featuring contemporary and historic artworks from the collection that span the globe including new acquisitions from Gio Swaby, Ebony Patterson, and Mary Sibande this exhibition highlights the ways that women preserve intergenerational skill-sharing and materialize maternal love through longstanding traditions in textile work.
The second iteration of Newfields staff art show.

**Working Title**  **Dates Tentative** 
A multimedia immersive exhibition produced by Grande Exhibitions. Set to a musical score, a thrilling display of over 3,000 inspirational images transforms every surface   walls, columns, and floors. Traditions of tiptoeing through unnervingly silent galleries and viewing paintings from afar are forgotten as visitors find themselves interacting with art.
***dates tentative*** Community members selecting artworks for display reveals new stories, connections, and/or points of interest in artworks from the IMA's permanent collection.

Femme Forward: Women in Design is a spotlight exhibition within the IMA s Design Gallery. Featuring works from the museum s collection, it examines the many modes of gatekeeping that have historically excluded women from the field of design, and how women designers have transgressed these barriers.

column7: Pop Up Park Install, IMA Cafe
column8:
A  Pop-Up Park  returns for its third season, transforming the Commons Area on the Ground Floor into a cozy winter oasis. The park will be redesigned for this edition, but expect communal seating areas to gather, a mobile version of The Public Collection lending library, a new music library and listening stations featuring tracks from Sound Expeditions and other locally commissioned work. Video and/or projection may also be incorporated. 
Installation components include, but are not limited to: faux turf, carpet squares, decking, furniture, bookshelves, lighting, sound equipment, painting, vinyl and graphics, signage, etc.

The project scope includes the following:Obtain rights for collection photography used in activity instructions, Provide edited collection photography for activity instructions,
Revise and print vinyl and sintra activity instructions (new magnet and hands-on activities), Supply designs for magnet activity to magnet distributor
Identify new hardware containers for hands-on materials if needed, Install and de-install vinyl, Touch-up paint as needed, and Document space following installation

The project scope includes the following: Obtain rights for photo and video, Provide edited photography, Develop light vs. pigment video, Design and print text and graphics, Repaint table, Install vinyl, and Install iPad

The project scope includes the following:Touch-up painting,Replace damaged vinyl,Identify backing for costume accessories (e.g. placing sintra behind beard and unibrow), Print new  Gallery Copy  stickers for books, Replace lighting as needed, Update activity materials as needed

Installation of interpretive signage in the greenhouse. Based on evaluation results from the orchids  exhibit, we will decide whether we want to keep some of the interpretive signage and add additional ones. Format will be similar to signage used for orchids  exhibit.

Installation of Made/Born/Lived/Worked in or Inspired by Indiana icon on 30 works from our collection/Lilly House/exhibitions and a couple of selected plants in the gardens. This will also require replacing some of the existing label to add a reference to Indiana in the text when it is not present, as well as connect the screen in Efroymson to minicomputer to show feeds of photo submitted by visitors.
Installation of a sign in the Art and Nature Park (ANP) explaining issues related to erosion.

Installation of one small birdhouse cam, bird feeders, and one high resolution camera near the Visitors  Pavilion in the park. Replacement of two small screens with larger screens in the visitors  pavilion. Installation will require assistance from Phil Day and IT, as well as from the crew for installing the screens. An exact date will be determined once we can order all equipment and cable in July and have a better sense of how long it will take for the delivery.
Installation of avian nesting platform and camera in Art and Nature Park with relevant signage.

Installation of bird feeders outside the Visitors Pavilion in the Art & Nature Park. Installation of bird cam pointing to the feeders and in the bird cage near the Visitor Pavilion. Installations of 2 screens in Visitor Pavilion showing the live feed from the bird house and from the bird nesting station (see other PUBS). Installation of labels next to the screens to explain the content of the screens. Installation of ANP bird brochure at VP including images of birds that can be seen at 100 Acres (images from istock).

Installation of viewing stations and relevant signage in Art & Nature Park. Installation of additional signage at Play Patch #2 and #3. Will need help from installations to ensure we get everything set properly with the viewing stations themselves.
Installation of mini lights and wreaths around Lilly House, Formal Garden, Cutting Garden and Greenhouse for Christmas at Lilly House: Holidays in Bloom.

Installation of Test it Lab IV in the balcony on upper Efroymson. We will test 4 activities: 1) Observation guide vs. postcards for Audubon, 2) Take Action activity for Audubon, 3) City as Canvas title + visual and 4) a didactic and/or installation to show people the results of touching a work of art. We will need help from the crew to install the Test It Lab title treatment and the reproductions of the Audubon prints. Design will need to provide some of the content to test (City as canvas visuals and do not touch didactic) and assist in the creation of the prototype for the Take Action Activity. Photography will provide some images (Audubon reproductions, City as Canvas visuals   already aware) and Rights and Reproductions will need to provide credits info for said images (I am compiling a list of all images needed and I will send it to Anne by the end of the week). DIME staff will take care of the rest of the installation and the deinstallation.

column7: Lilly House Spring Garden Photography Competition
column8: Lilly House Spring Garden Photography Competition. This will be a 2 phase project.  Phase 1 will open in conjunction with the Spring Blooms exhibition and will occupy two rooms on the 2nd floor of the Lilly House.  It will showcase photography by IMA staff, volunteers, and interns of Spring Blooms from last year.  These galleries will serve as inspiration for the public to take their own photos of the current Spring Blooms and submit them for a photography contest which will run for about 6-8 weeks.  Phase 2 will open after Spring Blooms is finished and will showcase prints by the winners of the photo contest. Phase 2 will be installed in a 3rd room  on the 2nd floor(green room) and will stay open throughout the summer.

Incorporate Japanese inspired floral arrangements and bonsai in Lilly House interiors. During the Spring, Summer, and Fall the Greenhouse Staff incorporates small seasonal displays in Lilly House, primarily on the two pedestals in the Dining Room and on the cabinet in the Stair Hall.   
For the Year of Japan we will design these floral/plant arrangements with a Japanese influence by incorporating inspiration from ikebana and bonsai. This is already an activity that is accomplished by the greenhouse staff we are simply using  Year of Japan  as the theme.

column8:
Reinstallation of Lilly House orientation plan based on the main guest entrance moving to the 1st Floor front door. 
Some furniture in the Great Hall and other select rooms will be removed or rearranged to make room for introductory/orientation didactics for guests as they enter the front door into the Great Hall. This area will act as a welcome area and introduce them to the house, its significance as a home to two prominent Indianapolis families and its architecture. Landon era blueprints (recreations) and Lilly era blueprints (facsimilie) will be used to show layout and changes to the house over time. Archive images and historic design plans will be used.
The basement hall will be reinstalled as a history of the Landon and Lilly families, showing family trees and a timeline of the estate showing the families  involvement and changes to the house and gardens. Archive images and graphics produced by Design will be used.
The main basement space will be reinstalled as an introduction/orientation to the gardens and surrounding landscape. Allowing guests to be reoriented to the gardens before leaving the house and continuing their visit on the grounds. Archive images, garden plans and graphics made by Design will be used. The orientation video will remain in the theater.
Reworking of Audio Guide will be needed.
New way finding will be needed throughout the house. 
New stanchion system will be explored.
Art adjacent pop-up venue installed in Efroymson Balcony.  Non-art installation.  This Culinary Arts pop-up venue will follow the Tea House Pop-Up.

Big Idea
Help Us Protect (formally Do Not Touch table) is a sensory learning experience designed to provide guests with an understanding of why art conservation is important.

Learning Outcomes:
1)	Damage: Guests will discover how different types of touch can damage artwork.
2)	Longevity: Guests will learn about factors that affect the longevity of artwork.
3)	Interaction: Guests will learn about the chemical interaction between their skin and artwork.
4)	Engagement: Guests will have the opportunity to help preserve the artwork for generations to come.   

Organizational Outcomes:
1)	Conservation: Guests will learn how the museum conserves artwork at Newfields. 
2)	Safety: Guests will learn how Newfields keeps the art and patrons safe.

At this time we are negotiating the physical form so location is TBD but possible places are: In-gallery, Efroymson, Upper Efroymson. It could look like a mobile device that can rotate between various different spots or something that is more permanent.

Public Eatery: Art adjacent pop-up venue installed in Upper Efroymson Balcony.  This will follow the Noddle Bar venue in the same location.  This will be during the Cafe closure so more food options will be offered.

Fallen Fruit is an art collaborative originally conceived in 2004 by David Burns, Matias Viegener and Austin Young. Since 2013, David Burns and Austin Young have continued the collaborative work.  Fallen Fruit began by mapping fruit trees growing on or over public property in Los Angeles. The collaboration has expanded to include serialized public projects, site-specific art installations and happenings in various cities around the world. By always working with fruit as a material or media, the catalogue of projects and works reimagine public interactions with the margins of urban space, systems of community and narrative real-time experience. Fallen Fruit s visual work includes an ongoing series of art installations, wallpapers, public fruit parks, and video works that explore the social and political implications of our relationship to fruit and world around us. Recent curatorial projects reindex the social and historical complexities of museums and archives by re-installing permanent collections through syntactical relationships of fruit as subject.

For Harvest 2021, I propose engaging Fallen Fruit to conduct a socially oriented research project to map the presence of fruit trees in public space in Indianapolis. In addition to a mapping project, I propose a community engagement project in partnership with Indy Parks and the City of Indianapolis in which fruit trees are planted in public spaces, focusing on public spaces within identified food deserts. These trees will eventually produce fruit that will be freely available to passersby.

Archives staff is working to strategically reduce our footprint in anticipation of forthcoming records transfers. While recognition/award/honors information should absolutely be documented, the objects themselves lack research value and divert limited capacity from permanent records.
Archives planned to dispose of plaques after photo documentation but Charles asked if we might consider for these to be displayed on a wall (perhaps along the long hallway to DeBoast).  In addition, he wondered if there are more recent awards and recognitions stored in people s offices and desk drawers that we have no documentation for.  Our best guess is that recent awards will be in HR, Marketing and Horticulture offices.
The Archives page in Newfields Connect addresses Archives procedures relating toawards/recognition materials  and their documentation.  The images created and the excel sheet documenting the awards will be retained permanently by Archives and made accessible to staff
Please view the list and images via OneDrive.

Fallen Fruit is an art collaborative originally conceived in 2004 by David Burns, Matias Viegener and Austin Young. Since 2013, David Burns and Austin Young have continued the collaborative work.  Fallen Fruit began by mapping fruit trees growing on or over public property in Los Angeles. The collaboration has expanded to include serialized public projects, site-specific art installations and happenings in various cities around the world. By always working with fruit as a material or media, the catalogue of projects and works reimagine public interactions with the margins of urban space, systems of community and narrative real-time experience. Fallen Fruit s visual work includes an ongoing series of art installations, wallpapers, public fruit parks, and video works that explore the social and political implications of our relationship to fruit and world around us. Recent curatorial projects reindex the social and historical complexities of museums and archives by re-installing permanent collections through syntactical relationships of fruit as subject.

In support of Harvest 2021 (FY22), I propose engaging Fallen Fruit to conduct a socially oriented research project to map the presence of fruit trees in public space in Indianapolis. In addition to a mapping project, I propose a community engagement project in partnership with Indy Parks and the City of Indianapolis in which fruit trees are planted in public spaces (including ANP), focusing on public spaces within identified food deserts. These trees will eventually produce fruit that will be freely available to passersby.

column7: Religion, Spirituality and the Arts Exhibit - Bret Waller Gallery
column8:
Religion, Spirituality and the Arts is a program 7 year old, Lilly Endowment funded program housed at IUPUI Arts & Humanities Institute.  The program is directed by Rabbi, Sandy Sasso.  A multi-disciplinary faculty leads conversations with local artists around the intersection of religious texts and contemporary artistic interpretation. Over 100 artists have participated to date. Each cohort has 10   15 graduate student or professional artists. Their work includes a final art object, poem/dance/music. In the past, month-long exhibitions have been held at the Harrison Center, CTS, Clowes Hall, the Anthenauem, JCC, etc. 
This year s class is centered on Noah s Ark and the Environmental Imagination.

RSA will provide insurance for the objects and understands there will not be security, climate control etc.  They also are in agreement with the size limitations, labeling on the back, strap hangers etc. 

They would like to exhibit in September   November timeframe if possible.

At this time they do not think they need The Tobey Theater or other performance venue.  They would host an exhibition opening.  

IMA would provide installation labor, title graphic, wall labels for each artwork.

Fehnel Interpretive Sign
An emerging theme within the Art and Nature Park is storm water management. As a first in a series of interpretive signs on this topic, the Fehnel Interpretive sign will not only provide an updated donor recognition sign, but also provide a space to discuss the unique way this garden area manages storm water.

column8: Dr Burnette would like us to print and hang photos that represent the breadth of what Newfields has to offer.  It should look alive and beautiful and be reflective of who we are.  Combine photos of artwork(maybe details?), galleries, gardens, ANP, Miller House, and Lilly House   some with patrons, some without.  The photos do not have labels and we will imbed credit lines when necessary.  We will however create a  cheat sheet  of descriptive captions that will live in the Admin Suite in case people inquire about what is in the photos.  This display is intended to switch out seasonally   one batch for spring/summer and one batch for fall/winter.  Because of this we will pick one photo size and images will be cropped to match.  Any artworks that are selected will have to be cleared for cropping.  Phil is researching a hanging system that will allow for easy switch out and reuse.  There will be approximately 20 total photos per rotation and we will start with fall/winter due to timing. Not all photos need to rotate with the season but definitely the outdoor/garden ones.

column7: Indiana Black Expo: We. The Culture Activation
column8: The digital interpretation tool from the We. The Culture: Works by the Eighteen Art Collective and a photobooth by Kyng Rhodes were included at the Indiana Black Expo Summer Celebration as part of the Cultural Arts Pavilion at the Indiana Convention Center.

Ten to fifteen sculptures with the theme of  Garden Monsters  will be installed in The Garden for the duration of the Harvest Season. These monsters will be all-weather designs created that will be accompanied by signage and an artist statement. Each sculpture will be secured to a six-foot T-stake that has been placed and secured by Horticulture. Sculptures can be as tall as eight feet high, eight feet wide (four feet on either side of the T-stake) and four feet deep to be distributed at the discretion of the artist and approval by Newfields team. This project is managed by Public Programs and Horticulture.

column8:
Art in Bloom will include 50 floral installations inspired by works of art throughout the IMA Galleries and the Lilly House. In 2024 we will have 43 pedestal installations 40 inside the IMA and three in the Lilly House. There will also be seven showstoppers six inside the IMA and one inside of the greenhouse atrium.

In addition to the floral installations we will have the following programmatic elements for every day of the show during general admission hours: plant & orchid market in Deer Event Pavilion (will include a  Plant Hotel  for holding while guests are in the galleries), live music in Pulliam, live talks in the Toby at 12 PM and floral demonstrations in DeBoest theater at 1, 2, 3 and 4 PM EST on the hour.

We will also be hosting ticketed content including the opening reception on Wednesday, March 20th; Floral Arranging Classes in The Pop Up on Thursday, March 21st; Meet the Designer Happy Hour on Friday, March 22nd; and Art in Bloom in Six Courses on Saturday, March 23rd.

We will also be working with the Staff Appreciation Committee and Random Acts of Flowers to preserve as many flowers as possible during deinstall on Sunday so that on Monday, staff can donate their time to make flower installations for Random Acts of Flowers to distribute to local retirement homes.

This is a mobile self-guided tour to celebrate Women s History Month. The tour will be created by interpretation, curatorial, and the lab. Led by interpretation. Support from marketing needed for signage and promotional materials./ / In times past, this project led to the spontaneous installation of new acquisitions. Therefore, this PUB could involve more departments depending on the executive team review.

column7: Indianapolis Public Library Story Walk - Fairbanks Park
column8: In collaboration with the Indianapolis Public Library (IPL), ANP and Public Programs are collaborating to bring a StoryWalk to the Virginia B. Fairbanks Art and Nature Park. The StoryWalk will feature  Wake Up, Woods  by Author Mike Homoya.  IPL has received permission from publisher, author, illustrator, and all other authorities for the use of the book in this way.  The Author will be present at the opening of the StoryWalk to give a walking lecture about spring ephemeral plants.

The posters will be used to line the hallway that leads to The Amphitheater and promotes both our annual film series and local artists. Like the Bigger Picture Show, the posters will be up for a silent auction throughout the summer. Newfields will retain a percentage of the final sale with a minimum payment to the artists. 

20 27  x 40  posters with frames   15-17 posters of the films, the rest for promotion of the film series.

column7: Clowes Ceiling Eclipse Media - Clowes Courtyard (C202)
column8:
In advance of and through the total solar eclipse on April 8, 2024, we propose adding a new audiovisual work into the existing Clowes Courtyard Digital Ceiling program, or to play between each cycle of the existing program (depending on details of agreement with Blockhouse Studios and internal plans for the future of Clowes Ceiling programming). This work will be developed internally by the Newfields Lab (Daniel Keller, lead developer), to tie in with and build anticipation for Newfields  eclipse celebration. 

We anticipate this work to have a runtime of 3-6 minutes, likely incorporating 3D assets from NASA s Scientific Visualization Studio (e.g., https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/4720) to create an artistic visual representation of a solar eclipse in space, set/synced to instrumental music that will play in the courtyard. Together, these elements will provide an immersive experience that guests have come to expect in the Clowes Courtyard. 

This is not a project that has been previously budgeted for a standalone project, but expenses should be covered within the eclipse project budget. Costs will be minimal. No new technology should need to be purchased. There is a possibility of licensing costs for music and one-time purchases of 3D textures to enhance the work.

Ritman is deinstalled, Miller is installed. Rotation begins 4/1/2013.

This collection rotation will include the work of three artists whose art addresses history and its telling in differing ways. There will be a vinyl didactic giving a thematic overview of the selection, with a title something along the lines of Alternative Histories. Kara Walkers cut paper and projection work critically addresses race, gender, and power through a reworking of illustration typical of the antebellum American South. Fact, fiction, and history also become complexly intertwined in the work of Omer Fast, whose landmark 4-channel video installation The Casting splices and interweaves a young U.S. Army sergeants recounting of two stories. The galleries will also display Capsule and Orbit by Indianapolis-based artist Brian McCutcheon. The sculpture, Capsule, re-imagines the historic Mercury space capsule Friendship 7 that in 1962 launched astronaut John Glenn into orbit around the Earth. Unlike NASAs gold-plated original, McCutcheon has customized the capsule like a hot rod car, and the accompanying video installation depicts he and his son reenacting Glenns voyage within the interior of Capsule.

Installation will begin 9/16/2013.

On November 21, the Indianapolis Museum of Art will unveil its new design arts galleries featuring more than 400 works of art. This installation will represent one of the largest displays of contemporary design in an American art museum and will focus on design after 1980, a period of immense growth fueled by two overarching concepts: design as industry and design as art. The new galleries will open to the general public on November 22.

Anna Huntington's Fawns Playing (38.40) will be deinstalled. The portrait medallion of Robert L. Stevenson (12.13) will shift from K212 to K209, and additional relief sculpture by Saint-Gaudens (10.241), Janet Scudder, Karl Bitter, and/or David K. Rubins will be installed in K209. The removal of the freestanding wall and the return of the 2 O Keeffe s will necessitate a full rehanging of the American Modernist gallery. The Chief Preparator may decide that this is an opportune time to repaint the gallery. If so, all works will have to be removed. The paperwork details which works will return or be added to the gallery and which ones will remain in storage. North wall, from left to right: O Keeffe s Pelvis with the Distance (77.229), O Keeffe s Jimson Weed (1997.131), O Keeffe s Grey Hills (43.37). East wall, from left to right: Dove s Reflections (2003.161), Higgins s Mountains and Valleys (73.104.2), Marin s Hurricane (61.42). South wall, from left to right: Lewis s Composition 1 (TR10179), Bolotowsky s Black Abstraction (72.11), Fisk s Rooftops, NYC (2002.166), Held s Manhattan Skyline (71.184), Criss (on loan from US GSA). column7: Early European Reinstall - H211, H212, H213, H214
column8: This project will combine the repainting of the Early European galleries, the installation of the wall in H214, the deinstallation of the Vigee-Lebrun painting for outgoing loan, and the installation of the Albacini. It will require the deinstallation of 3 works, the installation of three works, and the shifting of several works between galleries. On the west wall of H212, the Vigee-Lebrun (64.740), an outgoing loan, and the Rigaud (56.56) will be deinstalled and sent to storage. Boucher (60.248) and Pater (64.1), which currently hang in H213, will relocate to the space once occupied by V-L and Rigaud in H212. On the east wall of H213, Chardin (36.22) will be deinstalled and sent to storage; the height of Watteau (74.98) will be adjusted accordingly. The Canaletto (53.8) will relocate from H214 to the space once occupied by Pater and Boucher in H213.  On the southwest corner of H213, the oil sketches (1996.173; 56.106; 72.85.6; 71.5; 71.6) will be deinstalled. Appiani (72.85.6) will shift to H211, and be double-hung with Ingres (54.56)   please adjust height of Ingres accordingly. Giaquinto (1996.173), Carlone (56.106), Diana (71.5), and Conca (71.6) will relocate to the southeast corner of H214. The Panini pendants (50.5 and 50.6) will relocate from the north wall of H214 to the southwest corner of H213; Albacini (72.85.5) will be installed on a pedestal in this corner. A mid-sized didactic, placed in this corner, will discuss the significance of the Grand Tour in the 18-century. In H214, the Claude (2003.171) and Romanelli (72.18) will relocate to the north wall   please redirect the security camera to the Claude. The Maratti (1988.70) will relocate from the west wall to the north wall. The Vaccaro (57.209) will shift to the northeast corner of the gallery, the current location of the crucifix (1995.24). A freestanding wall will be constructed with the Virgin of Guadalupe (2008.361) on the east side, and the crucifix (1995.24) on the west side (provided that there is sufficient room). As of now, the plan for the west wall remains largely the same with the Giordano replacing the Maratti (1988.70). However, the works on this wall (Magnasco, Castello, Rizi, and Ricci) have been added to the checklist in case they shift during reinstallation. Please save all labels. As previously mentioned, a didactic is needed for H213. New labels are needed for Albacini, Virgin of Guadalupe, and Giordano (reprint existing copy).

column8: In K407, rotation out of light sensitive objects 2010.240A-H and 1992.288, resulting in a larger reordering that affects K407. The remaining rotations occurring in K411, W402, W403 and W404 are in keeping with continued efforts to  freshen up  the contemporary galleries with different thematic hangings, such as multi-paneled works in K402, and architecture in W404.

Display of Mrs. Lilly s Collection of porcelain Doughty and Boehm birds throughout various rooms at Lilly House during the run of Audubon. 
To add an interactive element we could produce a sheet or  field guide  for people to go on a  bird watch  in the house. Guests would be invited to try to find all the birds throughout the house during their visit. Small write ups of each bird would be included in handout. It could also possibly be tied to the gardens since each bird is situation in a vignette of flowers and plants.

column7: Gauguin Santa Caterina LO Return - H211

Rousseau shifts one space left, Courbet [39.3] shifts one space left, and the Pissarro [75.981] shifts slightly down vertically on the wall so that the Daubigny [39.79] can shift above it in a double-hang.

Conservation in Clowes for Spring 2017. 
Ambrosius Bosschaert s Flowers in a Glass Vase (small painting on panel) will be treated in the winter, and re-installed in the spring 2017 along with didactic panels highlighting the flower types and the infrared image. The painting may either be moved to make room for didactic panels or placed entirely on a separate wall in gallery C205 (same wall used for the two previous Conservation in Clowes exhibits)- tbd.
Objects will be removed based on Light Sensitivity.
Deinstallation and permanent relocation of LOVE by Robert Indiana (75.174) to Pulliam Great Hall.

This rotation will take place in the connecting gallery between H204 & H205. It includes a strong example of a Burne-Jones stained glass that has been off view for a number of years, William Morris patterned wallpaper and a Jean Morel nouveau cup that links the chronology of the two Dec Arts galleries.

In the spring of 2017, The Luxury of Tea and Coffee, Chinese Export Porcelain, Highlights from the Shirley M. Mueller Collection will be deinstalled in H205, and the objects that are not transferred to the larger showing of her collection at Lilly House will be returned to Mueller. In its place in H205 will be three vitrines exhibiting four objects from the Bressler and Norris silver collections, which were most recently displayed in Tiffany, Gorham, and the Height of American Silver, 1840   1930 at Lilly House. Through his relationship with the donors, Charles Venable is pursuing many of the objects from this exhibition to be promised gifts, and keeping them on rotating display in the museum s galleries will aid in these efforts.

Since Gauguin s Still Life with Profile of Laval [1998.167] may be published in the January issue of Indianapolis Monthly, we re putting it back out in the gallery before it leaves on loan. It will replace de Haan s Still Life with Apples and Vase of Flowers [2001.349].
Deinstall Gauguin s Still Life with Profile of Laval [1998.167] for loan to the AIC. Install de Haan s Still Life with Apples and Vase of Flowers [2001.349] in its place.

Lewis s Composition 1 [TR10179] will replace Abbott s Willow Street, Brooklyn [2002.32]. The other paintings on the wall may need to shift around at that time, and are therefore included on the checklist. Ellen would like to be there.

J. Teramoto proposes a gallery intervention in the Hurwitz gallery to highlight the art of Tibet and neighboring countries.  Four thangkas will be rotated on the wall and small pedestals would be installed to exhibit a selection of sculpture currently on display in the Thompson gallery and in storage. The large platform in Hurwitz will be moved back in to the center of the gallery and textiles will be wall mounted. Please see attached rough layout for the space.  All replacement objects have been identified. The time line suggested for this project would be from summer 2017 through summer 2018. It is also hoped that this installation would afford us the opportunity to organize a number of lectures and programs to help highlight the installation. Including an IMA Family Day in August of 2017 (this family would include the creation of a sand mandala in PGH).

At minimum we would need to reprint one didactic and have five new extended labels. Since many objects are moving in the gallery existing labels might need to be reprinted as well.

column7: Ramsey Kimbell San Francisco Boston LO Return
column8:
Upon return of  King George III  by Allan Ramsay [66.21B_B.2] and depending on the timeline of the Clowes galleries renovation, the painting will either be
a) Reinstalled around July or August 2018 and the temporary placard will come down.  (If  Queen Charlotte  gets centered on the wall during the loan period, then it will need to be re-adjusted so that it is side by side with  King George III. )
Or
b) It will go directly to Art Storage.
Flip Spellman [2016.51] from RECTO to VERSO, and then reinstall.

The 18th-century installation has not changed significantly since it was installed in the mid-2000s.  It is situated between two spaces that now have 19th- and 20th-century works of art in them and thus does not make sense chronologically.  Reinstalling the gallery with 19th-century decorative arts will tie together the storyline between the paintings galleries and 20th-century design for the visitor.   Also, the IMA is working to have several collections of exceptional silver donated and needs to continue to exhibit or borrow that material so the collectors understand how much we desire the objects. The overview would start around 1800 and end around 1910, where the timeline in the Zink Gallery next door picks up.  The cases in the center of the gallery will contain a  mini  exhibition of American and European objects in the Japanese taste.  The wall cases along the side walls will each be devoted to a single food or beverage (coffee, tea, meat, etc), or food group (seafood, dessert, etc) to demonstrate the specialized use of these objects.

We are integrating some of the best pieces from the Clowes Pavilion into H214 and H215. This proposal covers the period between the closing of the Clowes Pavilion and the end of the Clowes portraits exhibition in AWC (about July 9, 2018   August 18, 2019). The period between the end of the portraits exhibition and the reopening of the Clowes Pavilion (August 19, 2019   spring 2021) will be proposed separately.

This plan is on the condition that there is no Masterpiece Tour, which would include the bulk of the European paintings collection (both Clowes and non-Clowes works). Until we are certain that the tour will take place, we need to proceed with plans for what will happen if there is no tour.

In order to highlight the importance of certain works, and to emphasize their connection to others within gallery H214, I would like to incorporate a design element similar to what we ve done for the American decorative arts gallery (H203): a colored  pop-out  section of the wall behind the Rubens sketch (2001.237) and the Brueghel landscape (2000.343).

In 2016 we discovered that Vonnoh s A Young Mother [69.19] needed some serious conservation work before returning to the galleries. I m putting this request out there, recognizing it might not be possible in FY19, just in case we get a new objects conservator and they can consider working on it.

This reinstallation is a revamp of the Lilly House interpretation. It will include some art movement within the space, removal of works, but no new objects. This reinstallation coincides with opening the front door of Lilly House as the guest main entrance. 

Front door entrance will be regraded to eliminate the steps. First floor interpretation will focus on house architecture, changes to architecture and furnishings, and importance of the house; some objects may move to make way for this interpretation. Wayfinding will be added to stair hall. Lower level hallway will focus on Lilly family history and history of Oldfields. Lower Level will focus on the Gardens and the Landon family founding the estate. This will also be a space for the guests to reorient themselves to the gardens to continue their visit.

The large marble tablets by Karl Bitter [15.68-.69], plus the third [currently unnumbered] tablet that accompanies them will be installed in upper Efroymson. These pieces are A s in our collection, but very large and heavy, and haven t been moved in years, so budgeting and planning considerations include:
 	Equipment to move them to conservation (or another space selected by conservation) for conservation review

column7: Lilly House Main Entrance Deinstall - Lilly House
column8:
This is the rotation for the Lilly House Reinstallation 2019. This rotation encompases the reinstall after Deck the Halls at Lilly House/Winterlights 2018, plus the removal of objects for the upcoming Clowes Portrait exhibition. There are no new loans or lenders in this rotation. All objects that are going in were already on display prior to Deck the Halls at Lilly House/Winterlights 2018. Some objects are being removed or moving between rooms due to the front door becoming the primary entrance to the house and the need for a guest services presence in the Great Hall. 

This rotation/reinstall also includes additional/reworked wayfinding, new general signage for restooms, orientation theater etc. and new graphics for garden map on lower level.
A rotation should there be any new loans or acquisitions that we care to display. It might also be a good time to address a consistent narrative flow between this gallery and Zink.
Removal of [2016.362] ""Goelet" Racing Cup for Schooners" for Loan out. No object replacement needed. Remove pedestal from gallery. Trophy and pedestal will return to gallery in Sept. 2019.

column7: Art into Nature Discretionary - H200, H201
column8: In order to align our galleries with our rebranding as Newfields: A Place for Nature and the Arts, we propose reinstalling two prominent galleries on Floor 2 with European and American paintings/decorative arts that focus on landscapes and motifs from nature. Our three masterpieces (Gauguin, Czanne, van Gogh) would move out of H206, to assume better real estate in H200-H201. Discretionary  silver loans install. Curatorial outline from C.V. attached. Notes from C.V. email below.

Dear All, 
As some of you know, in the past few months and now over the holidays, I have had several conversations with key lenders that will necessitate changes in our silver gallery H205.
In brief, Richard Bressler has finalized his estate planning and we now know what silver he is going to donate to the IMA and which pieces he is going to either sell or leave to his children.  This will mean that we need to return a few pieces to him this spring and pick up two from his Seattle residence for shipment to the IMA. 
Steven and Karen Chambless have sent additional pieces on loan from their spectacular collection, which need to be worked into the installation.  Some of their new loans will need polishing.
Several local collectors have also acquired very fine pieces that are now promised to the IMA and need to be installed as well. 
Attached please find an outline of the changes that need to be made in H205.  I fully realize that rotations should ideally be planned much further in advance, but we need to move quickly to accommodate Mr. Bressler s desire to finalize his estate planning and to entice the Chambless  to begin making gifts to the IMA.    
Therefore, I suggest we gather together the required individuals and review these needed changes very soon so that we can get them accomplished as early in 2020 as possible.  Once we have a timeline I can inform the donors/lenders as to when they can come to Indianapolis and see their pieces in the gallery.

Return loans to Richard Bressler, pack them to hand carry. Notes from C.V. email below.

 The pieces that Richard Bressler wants back are: Tiffany place setting TR11763/2A-E and Salad bowl TR TR11809/6. Would it be possible to deinstall these pieces before mid-February so I could personally take them to Seattle?  Given the short notice I am fine with us simply putting temporally removed labels in the cases and then replacing the objects in April when we rearrange things in that gallery.    Please let me know if we can accomplish these removals in time.

Need to install a single case in the American Galleries to accommodate the loan of TR12307/4 Loving cup. A new pedestal is needed.

Could we potentially install on same date as ROT2020.40 if a pedestal and label copy are available?

column7: Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cezanne Replacements - H206
column8:
When our great triumvirate moves into LUME Gallery 3, two walls in H206 will be blank (south and east wall).  In conjunction with LUME, I propose bringing 6 paintings into this space on the theme of  Admirers of Vincent Van Gogh.  

Because the Hulman  I  will be closing at a date TBD (summer 2021), our Pointillists and Pont-Aven paintings will go off view. This proposal will get at least six of them out on view under a tight theme related to Van Gogh.  I expect that they could stay in that location even after LUME Y1.

column7: Design Power Couples Rotation - H300, H301, H302
column8: This rotation takes its theme from Whitney Chadwick and Isabelle De Courtivron s 1993 book Significant Others: Creativity and Intimate Partnership. In this rotation I will use objects from our collection to explore collaborative relationships with partners who are also romantic couples. I will attempt to unpack the roles each individual played in this partnership, and how in heterosexual couples the women s roles compared to that of the men. This checklist needs to be refined at a later date to ensure that all objects fit in the designated space and to incorporate as needed LS objects.

column7: Women in Design Reinstallation LS - H302
column8:
This Spotlight rotation will rotate out the Spotlight on Japanese Design currently installed in the Design Gallery s central platform, and replace it with a  Women in Design  theme. This platform was intended to be rotated every year, but as various teams related to these rotations have reduced bandwidth, this rotation will be more permanent.

We will use this opportunity to also address certain light sensitive items that have been in need of replacement for some time. Because there are so many light sensitive replacements, I would like to work with one of our exhibition designers on this and incorporate into the  Women in Design  rotation. See attached checklist for my initial notes on light sensitive replacements (there are a LOT!). If we replaced all of the works that need light sensitive rotation, that would be about 100 objects. I plan to work more closely with conservation and determine a more feasible number.

This will also be a chance to change out the three object-in-focus videos that have been on display in the Design gallery since 2018. I have consulted with Wednesday Rees about this and she will submit a separate PUB proposal for these videos.

column7: European Reinstallation - H200, H201, H205, H206
column8:
Due to changes in Hulman ( I  galleries) and the return of the Masterpiece Tour from China, a great number of our best European paintings are currently in storage.  An installation of European masterpieces in H210, H211, H212 H200, H201, H205 and H206 would serve to get some of these items back on view.  (Relegated to storage, for example, are important paintings by, among others, Canaletto, Fragonard, Gauguin, Goya, Hobbema, Jordaens, Kalf, Monet, Nosadella, Seurat, Stubbs, Turner, Valentin de Boulogne, and Victors.) 
An installation of this kind might be arranged chronologically, with the possibility of integrating several carefully selected small thematic groupings.  A 30-50% checklist would be determined by September 1, 2021, since the location for such a reinstallation was changed on July 21, 2021, and Kjell and I will need to meet in August to discuss.
Demolition of casework in H205 has been proposed, as well as preparation/repair of floors in that gallery and in H200/H201.
